newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: Anglo says Lonrho suggested Ashanti share swap.
newsitem.headline: Anglo says Lonrho suggested Ashanti share swap.

text.p: Mining giant Anglo American Corp of South Africa Ltd said on Wednesday Lonrho PLC had suggested a deal in which Anglo would gain the British company's stake in one of Africa's most succesful gold mining companies -- Ashanti Goldfields Company Ltd.

Anglo chairman Julian Ogilvie Thompson told analysts during a briefing on the company's annual report that Lonrho had mooted the idea of swapping its 33.6 percent stake in Ghana's Ashanti for Anglo American's disputed Lonrho stake.
Anglo said in April it would cut its 27 percent stake in Lonrho to less than 10 percent after pressure from the European Commission.
Analysts have said that Anglo desperately wants a stake in Ashanti -- among the most profitable gold mining companies in Africa with interests spread across the continent.

Lonrho and South Africa's JCI Ltd -- the first black-controlled mining house -- said last month they were holding preliminary negotiations which could see the creation of a mining powerhouse with a market capitalisation of over $3 billion.
Press reports at the time said both companies were looking for a merger deal under which Lonrho's stake in Ashanti would go to Anglo American.
In return, Anglo's stake in Lonrho would be bought back and cancelled by the British mining-to-hotels conglomerate.
Ogilvie Thompson said the proposed swap -- which will reduce Anglo's stake to EC expectations -- was initiated by Lonrho.
"The idea of possibly swapping our Lonrho shares for shares in Ashanti is an idea that came from the Lonrho side, not from us," he said.
Ogilvie Thompson said he also wanted to clear up a misconception that Anglo had initiated the possible merger between JCI and Lonrho.
"The idea of merging JCI with Lonrho came from JCI, not from ourselves... We are not, so to speak, running this thing."
Anglo has suffered a series of setbacks this year.

In addition to having to back down and agree to cut its Lonrho stake because the European Union saw two companies' combined platinum interests as constituting a monopoly of the world's platinum industry, Anglo also lost out on two more lucrative deals.

In the new Democratic Republic of the Congo, the company lost out on a bid to develop a major copper and cobalt project at Kolwezi, which President Laurent Kabila's government awarded to America Mineral Fields.
And in Brazil, an Anglo American-led consortium lost a bid last month for Brazil's mining giant CVRD.

CVRD was purchased by an international consortium led by Brazilian steelmaker CSN which bid $3.15 billion for 41.73 percent of voting CVRD share capital -- 20 percent above the minimum share price of $25.
Ogilvie Thompson said on Wednesday the company was obviously disappointed at losing the bid, but added Anglo was not prepared to overpay.
"There is only one thing worse than disappointment and that is paying too much," he said.
